For Release Monday, Jan 1
Ahead to the '90s: Stock Traders Seek To Dodge Recession Risk
DOC.TEXT: As the economy heads into choppy waters in 1990, many investors will try to ride out the storm with what they hope are recession-resistant stock portfolios. For the last several months, managers at investing institutions have been putting their money in stocks whose fortunes appear least exposed to the ups and downs of the business cycle. At the same time, they have been shunning auto, steel and other industrial issues that would presumably be most affected by the first general economic slump since the 1981-82 recession. ``The economy's slowing down, no question about it,'' says Peter Lynch, who runs the Fidelity Magellan Fund, the nation's largest stock mutual fund with $12.4 billion in assets. ``When that happens cyclical stocks just don't do very well.'' The risk of an economy-wide slump ``is higher than at any time since the 1982 recession,'' says Martin Sass, president of M.D. Sass Investors Services Inc., an independent money-management firm with $3.8 billion in accounts. Still, Sass assigns only a 25 percent probability to that outcome, and says he believes lower interest rates and inflation can help bring new life in 1990 to Wall Street's bull market. ``Certainly it's not the early innings of the ball game,'' he observes. ``But I think there's still some more room here.'' It's no simple trick to devise a stock-picking strategy for gains in a rising market while minimizing exposure to losses should prices decline. The traditional way to do that is to concentrate on ``defensive'' stocks like high-yielding utilities and those of companies with steady, year-in, year-out earnings growth. So it comes as no surprise that ``consumer noncyclical'' and utility stocks ranked first and second in 1989 among the eight sectors of the stock market tracked by Dow Jones & Co. From the end of 1988 through Dec. 26, the consumer noncyclical index rose 37.86 percent, while the overall Dow Jones equity market index posted a 24.27 percent gain. The utility index climbed 34.34 percent. That struck a marked contrast with increases of just 15.65 percent for the industrial sector, and 5.1 percent for technology stocks. Lynch says those divergent trends have lifted the big-name consumer stocks to expensive levels. Cyclical stocks may look cheaper, he says, but they could go lower still if the business outlook keeps darkening. ``I'm still buying stocks every day, but I've been letting cash build up'' to about 11 percent of the Magellan Fund's assets, he says. ``I'm not finding many outstanding, attractive bargains.'' Sass, for his part, thinks the time has come to buy cyclical issues in such industries as paper, aluminum, steel and chemicals. ``The cyclical stocks have gotten killed,'' he asserts. ``Many of them are trading at levels that already discount a recession, in my view. ``These companies have gotten more lean, more efficient. But the stocks are very much out of favor, and hardly anyone is recommending them.'' Sass pins his hopes that a recession can be avoided partly on what he sees as a renewed easing of inflationary pressures as the economy slows. ``The inflation rate could be a positive surprise'' in 1990, he says. He also argues that slowdowns in the pace of business can keep occurring in separate areas of the economy, as they did through much of the 1980s, without bringing on a recession. ``These rolling readjustments,'' he concludes, ``will permit the long U.S. expansion which began in late 1982 to enter its eight consecutive year, the longest peacetime expansion on record.''
